title-group.article-title: Recanalization of Iatrogenic Dissection of the Superior Mesenteric Artery
title-group.subtitle: A Case Report

article-meta.aff: 2Tokyo Medical University Hachioji Medical Center, Tokyo, Japan

abstract.p: We present a case of acute abdominal pain due to a long-segment iatrogenic superior mesenteric artery dissection, which was immediately treated successfully with balloon fenestration of the intimal flap, resulting in complete resolution of the symptoms without recurrence during the 2-year follow-up period.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Iatrogenic dissection of the superior mesenteric artery (SMA) during catheterization is a rare complication. 1–3 Depending on the patient’s symptoms, conservative or more aggressive treatments such as surgery may be performed. We report a case that was successfully treated with immediate recanalization of the iatrogenic dissection of the SMA with balloon fenestration of the intimal flap as a possible new therapeutic approach.

sec.title: Case Report
sec.p: A 82-year-old man underwent transarterial chemoembolization (TACE) for hepatitis C-related recurrent hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC). Usual procedures, such as local anesthesia to the right inguinal area and introducer placement to the right femoral artery, were performed to facilitate easy catheter use. A 4F hook-shaped catheter (Angiomaster; Terumo Co Ltd, Tokyo, Japan) was inserted to the SMA ostium. It was further inserted at the distal side of the inferior pancreatic duodenal artery along the 0.035-inch guidewire (Radifocus guidwire; Termo Co Ltd) referring to the computed tomography (CT) arterial portography. When a test injection of contrast medium was performed by hand to confirm the location of the catheter tip, a long-segment dissection of the SMA from the ostium was seen with severe compression of the true lumen from the expansion of the false lumen (Figure 1). The pooling of contrast medium within the false lumen was still observed after the test injection (Figure 2), and the patient complained of severe abdominal pain. From these findings, a diagnosis of acute mesenteric ischemia with the collapse of the true lumen and diminished arterial flow to the branches of the SMA was made.

caption.p: Selective angiography of the SMA shows a long-segment dissection of the SMA from the ostium with severe compression of the true lumen from the expansion of the false lumen. SMA indicates superior mesenteric artery.
The contrast medium still remains at the false lumen (arrows).

sec.p: To relieve the ischemia, endovascular therapy was performed to reperfuse the branches of the SMA. To create a recanalization route, the introducer was exchanged for a 4F guiding sheath catheter (MS kit; Medikit, Japan), which was placed at the SMA ostium. As the true lumen of the SMA was severely compromised, it was impossible to navigate the microguidewire (Begin; Asahi Intecc Co Ltd, Japan) through it. Instead, since a balloon catheter (Ryujin Plus; Terumo Co Ltd) was easily inserted into the false lumen, a percutaneous balloon fenestration of the dissection of the SMA was performed. The microguidewire perforated the intimal flap and reached the distal true arterial lumen of the SMA. The balloon catheter was then inserted along with the microguidewire across the intimal flap. A contrast medium injected by hand confirmed the balloon catheter tip was in the true arterial lumen. And then the fenestration of the intimal flap was performed (Figure 3). After the balloon fenestration, the superior mesenteric angiography revealed a decompression of the false lumen and an immediate recanalization of the true lumen (Figure 4), which resulted in complete resolution of the symptoms. The patient received heparin therapy and was maintained for 48 hours followed by antiplatelet therapy.

caption.p: Balloon fenestration of the intimal flap was performed for a 2 mm by 20 mm balloon.
Selective angiography of the superior mesenteric artery (SMA) after the balloon fenestration shows a recanalization of the true lumen.

sec.p: The TACE for HCC was not performed at this time. A follow-up CT scan, performed 4 days after the balloon fenestration, revealed the patency of both the true and the false lumens of SMA (Figure 5). After 1 month, the TACE procedure was successfully performed; TACE was repeated 4 times thereafter during the follow-up period. The patient died of progressive HCC without abdominal symptoms 2 years after the balloon fenestration.

caption.p: A computed tomography (CT) scan demonstrates the pate-ncy of both the true and the false lumens of the superior mesenteric artery (SMA). Arrow indicate intimal flap.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: The SMA dissection is usually associated with severe acute abdominal pain, which is considered to be due to the dissection itself or mesenteric ischemia. In this case, SMA dissection occurred during the procedure of TACE, such as manipulation procedures of guidewires and catheters and contrast material injections.

Reported treatment includes surgical treatment, endovascular repair, and conservative treatment. Especially in cases with clinical symptoms (mesenteric ischemia), surgical revascularization of the SMA is often attempted, 1,4 but recent reports have described percutaneous endovascular placement of stent as a safe and clinically effective therapy. 3,5,6 In this case, the true lumen of the SMA was severely collapsed, and it was impossible to advance the microguidewire into the true lumen from SMA ostium. Therefore, we used a balloon fenestration technique and recanalized the artery instead of a stent placement.

Originally, balloon fenestration was used in the treatment of true lumen collapse in aortic dissection. 7 Balloon fenestration aims at decreasing the inflow-to-outflow capacity ratio of the false lumen by widening an existing or artificially created re-entry tear, leading to reopening of the true lumen and reperfusion of the compromised branch vessels. 8 Although recently some cases of dissections of visceral arteries treated with balloon fenestration have been reported, 9,10 to our knowledge, SMA dissections treated with balloon fenestration have not. In this case, balloon fenestration of the intimal flap immediately reopened the true lumen of the branch vessels, which resulted in complete resolution of the symptoms.
In conclusion, immediate balloon fenestration may be a possible method of treating iatrogenic dissection of the SMA in case where endovascular stent placement is unavailable.
